Bumped on the hindquarters at the start.  The Stewards deferred the declaration of weighed-in as they were of the view that an incident had occurred near the 200 Metres which cast doubt on whether SANTORINI (K Teetan) should be declared the winner of the race.  Subsequently L Hewitson, the rider of KARATE EXPRESS, 2nd placegetter, lodged a protest/objection against SANTORINI being declared the winner alleging interference near the 200 Metres.  After considering the evidence including the patrol films, the Stewards found that KARATE EXPRESS initially shifted out and away from SANTORINI and became awkwardly placed close to PATCH OF COSMO, but could not be comfortably satisfied that KARATE EXPRESS had established clear running between SANTORINI and PATCH OF COSMO near the 200 Metres.  Whilst they were satisfied that SANTORINI had shifted out a short distance later and hampered KARATE EXPRESS, as they could not comfortably satisfied that KARATE EXPRESS had established clear running, the protest/objection was overruled and weighed-in was declared on the numbers semaphored by the judge.  K Teetan was advised to exercise more care.  L Hewitson pleaded guilty to a careless riding charge for causing interference over the concluding stages (see PATCH OF COSMO).  Sent for sampling post-race.

When questioned, Z Purton stated that he was given no specific instructions due to the wide barrier that his mount commenced from.  He said when KA YING RESILIENCE jumped well today, he elected to make use of his mount in the early stages to go forward.  He said when caught wide he was obliged to continue to ride his mount forward to cross to the lead to avoid racing wide, but when being shifted in to cross to the lead near the 1000 Metres, his mount commenced to race keenly and got its head up for a short distance thereafter.  He added KA YING RESILIENCE continued to race keenly throughout the middle stages.  Trainer D A Hayes confirmed that he issued no specific instructions to Jockey Purton and that Jockey Purton was to ride the horse dependent upon how it commenced today.

L Ferraris, who weighed in at 123 lbs, was fined the sum of $3,000 for returning to scale 2 lbs overweight.  Near the 1150 Metres was bumped by GOOD PROSPECT which shifted in slightly, resulting in PATCH OF COSMO becoming unbalanced.  L Hewitson (KARATE EXPRESS) pleaded guilty to a charge of careless riding [Rule 100(1)] in that over the concluding stages he allowed his mount to shift out when not clear of PATCH OF COSMO, resulting in PATCH OF COSMO being contacted by KARATE EXPRESS and being taken from its rightful running.  Having regard to Jockey Hewitson holding confirmed riding engagements for the remainder of the season and in accordance with previous practices, he was fined the sum of $60,000 in lieu of a one-day suspension.  In assessing penalty, the Stewards determined the carelessness grade 1 and the consequences grade 2 and also considered his good careless riding record.

The Stewards today inquired into the circumstances of SAVVY CHIC being entered for this event when it had been treated with an inhale bronchodilator medication inside the recommended withdrawal period, which resulted in SAVVY CHIC being withdrawn from this event by order of the Stewards on 3 July 2024.  Evidence was today taken from Mr F C Lor, trainer of SAVVY CHIC.  It was established that due to the late closure of entries for this event the stable had not implemented the usual warning systems to prevent the treatment within the recommended withdrawal period.  Mr Lor was fined the sum of $20,000 under Rule 50(5) for failing to adhere to the requirements of Trainers’ Handbook Regulation 69(h) in that he failed to take all proper precautions to ensure the recommended withdrawal period is applied to the administration of any medication containing a prohibited substance.  Before being allowed to race again, SAVVY CHIC will be subjected to an official veterinary examination.

He said as BABY CRYSTAL hung out throughout the event, he shifted his weight to the right side of his mount in an endeavour to encourage it to move closer to the rail. When questioned, C Y Ho stated that his instructions were to hold an on-pace position but not specifically to lead the event.  He said when joined in the lead by SEA SAPPHIRE in the early stages, his intention was to allow that runner to cross and he would race with cover behind SEA SAPPHIRE.  He said as he endeavoured to allow SEA SAPPHIRE to cross his mount, FUN N FUN TOGETHER commenced to race keenly and would not respond to his urgings to settle which resulted in a faster pace being set than what he would have liked.  The Stewards found the tactics adopted by Jockey Ho were reasonable in the circumstances in that he had made sufficient effort to endeavour to restrain his mount to attempt to set a more sustainable pace throughout the early and middle stages of the event.

When questioned regarding his riding and the fast pace set in the early and middle stages, K Teetan stated that his instructions were to endeavour to lead.  He said after SEA SAPPHIRE commenced well, he was joined in the lead by FUN N FUN TOGETHER.  He said having regard to his instructions, he then allowed SEA SAPPHIRE to stride forward with a view to crossing FUN N FUN TOGETHER in the early stages.  He added when FUN N FUN TOGETHER commenced to race keenly to his inside, he was unable to cross that runner approaching the first turn near the 900 Metres and as a result he elected to make additional use of his mount to cross FUN N FUN TOGETHER so as to comply with his instructions.  He said after the 700 Metres SEA SAPPHIRE was able to cross FUN N FUN TOGETHER to lead on the rail. Trainer P C Ng confirmed the instructions issued but stated such instructions were not binding and that the option was available to race outside the lead if SEA SAPPHIRE was unable to lead.  After considering his explanations, the Stewards advised K Teetan that he had made an error of judgement in the early stages by continuing to ride his mount forward to cross FUN N FUN TOGETHER, particularly when the early and middle stages of the event were run inside of standard time.  He was further advised he would be expected to show better judgement than what he did on this occasion in future.  A veterinary inspection immediately following the race did not show any significant findings.

When questioned, Z Purton stated that his instructions from the outside barrier were to ride his mount in a forward position, particularly with the expected lack of early pace in the event.  He said the instructions issued today were similar to those issued at the horse’s last start, however, LUCKY TOUCH was caught wide in the early stages due to that race being run at a faster pace than today.  He said as a result LUCKY TOUCH settled back on that occasion.  He added that approaching the first turn today he was able to obtain a position with cover behind the equal leader LAUGH TALE, but when MEEPMEEP improved to his outside near the 800 Metres, he was obliged to shift to the outside of LAUGH TALE as he was concerned that runner would not take him into the race.  He said as a result LUCKY TOUCH raced wide and without cover from that point before responding only fairly to his riding in the Home Straight.  He further stated that, in his opinion, having regard to the manner in which his mount raced today, it may be better suited being ridden in a conservative manner in the early stages.  Trainer J Richards confirmed the instructions issued and stated they were consistent with the instructions at the horse’s last start and also were issued as he felt it would be advantageous to race in an on-pace position on today’s "C” course.  A veterinary inspection immediately following the race did not show any significant findings.  Sent for sampling post-race.
Jumped only fairly and from a wide barrier was shifted across behind runners in the early stages. Bumped near the 250 Metres.

Sent for sampling post-race.

Jumped only fairly.  After the race, C Y Ho reported that his mount, which was having it second race start in Hong Kong, would derive benefit from toady’s performance.  A veterinary inspection immediately following the race did not show any significant findings.

After the race, Y L Chung stated that whilst his mount was obliged to race wide and without cover, it raced "flat” today.

When questioned regarding the performance of THUNDER BLINK, M Chadwick stated that from a favourable barrier the intention was to endeavour to hold a midfield position.  He said THUNDER BLINK jumped only fairly and then was quickly crossed by runners to his outside which resulted in his mount settling back in the field.  He added with the middle stages of the event being run outside of standard time, THUNDER BLINK did not travel well and for this reason he elected to allow his mount to follow SUNLIGHT POWER into the event from the 800 Metres.  He added his initial intention was to improve to the inside of SUNLIGHT POWER making the Home Turn but when BEAUTY GLORY commenced to give ground in advance, he was obliged to shift to the outside of SUNLIGHT POWER to obtain clear running.  He further stated that when placed under pressure in the Home Straight THUNDER BLINK, which was having its only third race start in Hong Kong, lay out and did  not respond to his riding which he attributed to the horse’s inexperience.  Trainer K H Ting confirmed the instructions were to endeavour to hold a more forward position and stated that with THUNDER BLINK stepping up to Class 3 grade today, its inexperience resulted in it not being able to race in a competitive manner.  He added that THUNDER BLINK would now be given a let-up for the remainder of the season.  A veterinary inspection immediately following the race did not show any significant findings.  The performance of THUNDER BLINK was considered to be disappointing as compared to its previous race starts.  Before being allowed to race again, THUNDER BLINK will be required to perform to the satisfaction of the Stewards in a barrier trial and be subjected to an official veterinary examination.   Sent for sampling post-race.
No report.

Having regard to Jockey Ho holding confirmed riding engagements for the remainder of the season and in accordance with previous practices, he was fined the sum of $50,000 in lieu of a one-day suspension. In assessing penalty, the Stewards determined the carelessness grade 2 and the consequences grade 2 and also considered his excellent race riding record.

He added in the Home Straight MIGHTY STEED finished the race off in a one-paced manner, however, after the 200 Metres became held up behind LOVERO before shifting to that runner’s outside at the 150 Metres.  The Stewards advised Jockey Chadwick that over the final 150 Metres he is required to ride his mount with more vigour than what he did on this occasion to ensure that it finishes in the best possible placing in the field.

He said when a run did not fully develop between POLARIS and LO PAN SPIRIT, he then contemplated shifting to the outside of LO PAN SPIRIT near the 400 Metres to secure clear running.  He said when MODULECONSTRUCTION was positioned to his outside and there was no run available, he then commenced to look to improve to the inside of LO PAN SPIRIT.  He added approaching the 300 Metres when he attempted to obtain that run, STAR CLUB improved to his inside at which point he received a call from the rider of STAR CLUB, Jockey Z Purton.  He said for this reason he was unable to fully commit to the run between LO PAN SPIRIT and POLARIS which resulted in GREAT STATE being held up behind LO PAN SPIRIT between the 300 Metres and the 200 Metres before GREAT STATE finished the race off only fairly.  The Stewards advised Jockey De Melo that in the circumstances he should have ridden his mount in a more decisive manner approaching the 300 Metres to ensure that he fully established a run between LO PAN SPIRIT and POLARIS sooner.

The Stewards opened an inquiry into Z Purton’s riding of NEBRASKAN with particular emphasis placed on the vigour he applied on the horse in the Home Straight.  Evidence was taken from Jockey Purton and Trainer J Size.  Z Purton explained that his instructions were to ride his mount in a forward position and after riding NEBRASKAN along in the early stages, NEBRASKAN shifted ground in the Back Straight and making the turn after the 600 Metres lay out which required him to have to apply pressure to his right rein to correct his mount.  He said on entering the Home Straight NEBRASKAN continued to shift ground which impacted upon his ability to apply full vigour to the horse in the Home Straight.  He added that after making contact with PRINCE OF PORTY passing the 175 Metres and with LEAN MASTER near the 150 Metres, he was then concerned that NEBRASKAN would continue to shift ground and for this reason he did not apply full vigour to NEBRASKAN between the 150 Metres and the 50 Metres.  He further stated that when he was satisfied that NEBRASKAN was properly balanced, he was able to ride NEBRASKAN out to the finish over the final 50 Metres.  Mr Size confirmed the instructions were to hold a forward position.  After considering the evidence, the inquiry was adjourned to a date and time to be fixed.  A veterinary inspection immediately following the race did not show any significant findings. <14/7/2024 Adjourned Injury – 10 July 2024 Happy Valley Racemeeting – Race 7 (818)> The Stewards today resumed their inquiry which was adjourned on 10 July 2024 in relation to Z Purton’s handling of NEBRASKAN in this event.  Further evidence today was taken from Jockey Purton and Mr J Size, trainer of NEBRASKAN.  Evidence today was also taken from Mr T Lam, part-owner of NEBRASKAN.  The Stewards also considered a detailed report from the Racing Integrity and Betting Analysis Department of the Club which reported that NEBRASKAN was well supported with its odds contracting from 9.8 to 7.85 just prior to the commencement of the event and there was no irregular market moves identified in any other betting platform.  On this basis the Stewards were satisfied that there was no integrity concern in relation to the running of this event.  Having considered further explanation provided by Jockey Purton today, the Stewards were satisfied:
No report.

Shifted in at the start, resulting in its rider C L Chau having to correct his mount. He said in the Home Straight KA YING WARRIOR failed to respond to his riding and raced in a disappointing manner.  A veterinary inspection immediately following the race did not show any significant findings.  The performance of KA YING WARRIOR was considered to be disappointing as compared to its previous race starts.  Before being allowed to race again, KA YING WARRIOR will be required to perform to the satisfaction of the Stewards in a barrier trial and be subjected to an official veterinary examination.

Near the 350 Metres blundered badly after striking the heels of BRILLIANT EXPRESS (H Bowman).  The Stewards established that near the 350 Metres BRILLIANT EXPRESS commenced to improve to the outside of HAPPY PARK when that runner shifted in towards the rail.  BRILLIANT EXPRESS then shifted out slightly and was contacted on the hindquarters by AMAZING RUN, resulting in BRILLIANT EXPRESS being turned out and its rider H Bowman having to correct his mount.  H Bowman was reprimanded for not making a greater effort to prevent his mount from shifting out.  However, the Stewards were satisfied that the shift out from BRILLIANT EXPRESS was principally due to the contact on its hindquarters.  A veterinary inspection immediately following the race which included an endoscopic examination showed a substantial amount of blood in the horse’s trachea.  Before being allowed to race again, AMAZING RUN will be subjected to an official veterinary examination.

B Thompson (LOST CHILD) pleaded guilty to a charge of careless riding [Rule 100(1)] in that near the 900 Metres he allowed his mount to shift in when not clear of PATCH OF THETA, taking PATCH OF THETA across the running of GIDDY UP, resulting in GIDDY UP being checked when it lost its running to the inside of PATCH OF THETA.  In accordance with previous practices, B Thompson was fined the sum of $25,000 in lieu of a one-day suspension.  In assessing penalty, the Stewards determined the carelessness grade 2 and the consequences grade 2 and also considered his excellent careless riding record.  After the race, A Hamelin stated that, in his opinion, the horse may not have appreciated the 7-day backup from its last start.  A veterinary inspection immediately following the race did not show any significant findings.

B Thompson pleaded guilty to a careless riding charge for causing interference near the 900 Metres (see GIDDY UP).  After the race, B Thompson stated that when his mount jumped well, he elected to go forward on LOST CHILD.  He said in the early stages when caught wide he was obliged to make use of his mount to shift closer to the rail.  He added as a result LOST CHILD did not finish the race off in the Home Straight.  A veterinary inspection immediately following the race revealed that the horse was displaying an irregular heart rhythm.  Before being allowed to race again, LOST CHILD will be required to perform satisfactorily in a barrier trial and be subjected to an official veterinary examination.

K C Leung was found guilty of a careless riding charge for causing interference shortly after the start (see SUPREME AGILITY).  K C Leung will be questioned as to whether he used his whip forward of the saddle over the concluding stages.  Sent for sampling post-race. <14/7/2024 10 July 2024 Happy Valley Racemeeting – Race 9 (820)> K C Leung was fined the sum of $5,000 for using his whip on a horse forward of the saddle.

Crowded shortly after the start.  After improving into a tight run to the inside of FLAMINGO TRILLION near the 100 Metres then lay in and away from that runner for a short distance thereafter, resulting in its rider H Bowman having to correct his mount.  Prior to declaring weighed-in, Jockey H Bowman and Trainer W K Mo viewed the patrol films to ascertain if there were grounds for a protest/objection against FLAMINGO TRILLION being declared the winner in relation to an incident which occurred inside the 100 Metres.  When Jockey Bowman and Trainer Mo declined to lodge a protest/objection and the Stewards were satisfied that there were not grounds to do so, weighed-in was declared on the numbers semaphored by the Judge.  Sent for sampling post-race.

L Ferraris was fined $2,000 for initially presenting himself to be weighed out with the incorrect saddle cloth number.  After the 200 Metres was bumped by ROMANTIC LAOS which shifted in.  Over the final 100 Metres raced tight to the inside of ROMANTIC LAOS.
No report.

K C Leung (FLAMINGO TRILLION) was found guilty of a charge of careless riding [Rule 100(1)] in that shortly after the start he allowed his mount to shift in when insufficiently clear of RISING FROM ASHES, resulting in RISING FROM ASHES being taken in and also forcing ROMANTIC LAOS onto SUPREME AGILITY, resulting in SUPREME AGILITY having to be checked and losing its running between ROMANTIC LAOS and AWESOME FLUKE.  Having regard to Jockey Leung holding confirmed riding engagements for the last racemeeting and in accordance with previous practices, he was fined the sum of $35,000 in lieu of a one-day suspension.  In assessing penalty, the Stewards determined the carelessness grade 2 and the consequences grade 2 and also considered his very good race riding record within his last 200 rides.  Sent for sampling post-race.
Jumped only fairly.

Before being allowed to race again, RISING FROM ASHES will be required to perform satisfactorily in a barrier trial and be subjected to an official veterinary examination. <14/7/2024 10 July 2024 Happy Valley Racemeeting – Race 9 (820)> Raced wide and without cover for the majority of the event.
